title: Larry David: My Dinner With Adolf
abstract: When a private meeting goes unexpectedly.

title: ‘60 Minutes’ Chief Resigns in Emotional Meeting: ‘The Company Is Done With Me’
abstract: The news program has faced mounting pressure from both President Trump and its corporate ownership at Paramount, the parent company of CBS News.

title: Under Hegseth, Chaos Prevails at the Pentagon
abstract: The defense secretary’s inner circle is in disarray, and distrust is growing among civil servants and senior military officials.

title: With Latest Missteps, Veneer of Discipline in 2nd Trump Term Falls Away
abstract: The mistakes, miscommunications and flip-flops are piling up after an early run defined by a flood of major policy changes that were rolled out at breakneck speed.

title: Palin Loses Libel Retrial Against New York Times
abstract: After two hours of deliberation, a jury rejected Sarah Palin’s claim that a 2017 editorial defamed her.

title: Trump Joins a Bitter Fight on Long Island Over a School Mascot
abstract: New York’s education leaders moved to ban Native American-inspired mascots in 2022, drawing a lawsuit from the Massapequa school district. Now, the president has weighed in.

title: Who Will Be the Next Pope? Here Are Some Possible Contenders.
abstract: Experts say there isn’t a single front-runner, but several names have been cited as indications of which direction the Roman Catholic Church might take.

title: Six Men Are Charged After Woman Was Dragged From Idaho Town Hall
abstract: The plainclothes guards were involved in the forcible removal of a woman from a meeting hosted by local Republicans in Coeur d’Alene, prosecutors said.

title: At Least 24 Tourists Gunned Down by Militants in Kashmir
abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India called the shooting, the worst against civilians in the region for years, a “terror attack” and vowed to bring the perpetrators to justice.

title: An Immigrant Held in U.S. Custody ‘Simply Disappeared’
abstract: The Venezuelan man did not appear on a list of people sent to a prison in El Salvador, and his family and friends had no idea of his whereabouts.

title: Elon Musk Vows to Spend Less Time in Washington as Tesla’s Profit Drops 71%
abstract: The carmaker reported the sharp decline in quarterly earnings after its brand suffered because of its chief executive’s role in the Trump administration.

title: Melania Trump’s Easter Surprise
abstract: For the White House Easter Egg Roll, the first lady opted for, of all things, a trench coat.

title: Rubio Skipping Ukraine Talks as Zelensky Rebuffs U.S. on Crimea
abstract: The decision by Secretary of State Marco Rubio to pull out of the meeting and an objection by Ukraine’s leader to a key U.S. proposal raised questions about the state of the negotiations.

title: The Face-Plant President
abstract: There’s no better opponent than one who repeatedly trips over his shoelaces.

title: Trump Tried to Derail Our Work. We Banded Together and Moved Forward.
abstract: When knowledge is threatened, don’t just mourn it. Build around it.

title: Kristi Noem’s Bag, With Security Badge and $3,000, Is Stolen
abstract: The homeland security secretary was dining at a Washington, D.C., restaurant. She also lost her passport and keys.

title: Trump Promised ‘Big, Beautiful’ Deals. Delivering Has Been Tougher.
abstract: So far, the goals of many of President Trump’s negotiations have been unrealized, even those he said would be accomplished in a matter of days or weeks.

abstract: Harvard frantically tried to avoid a showdown with the Trump administration. Now many of its big donors are pushing the university’s leaders to back down and renew talks with the White House.

title: MAGA Natalism Is Doomed to Fail
abstract: Trump will never be the “fertilization president.”

title: I Caught a Glimpse of the New World Order in Greenland
abstract: Whom Greenlanders choose to do business with — economically, politically and socially — will tell us a lot about the coming global realignment.

title: Trump Officials Blame Mistake for Setting Off Confrontation With Harvard
abstract: An official on the administration’s antisemitism task force told the university that a letter of demands had been sent without authorization.

title: Hegseth Said to Have Shared Attack Details in Second Signal Chat
abstract: The defense secretary sent sensitive information about strikes in Yemen to an encrypted group chat that included his wife and brother, people familiar with the matter said.

abstract: Lisa Murkowski, a longtime senator from Alaska and an independent voice in an increasingly tribal party, has been the rare Republican on Capitol Hill willing to criticize President Trump’s actions.

abstract: Further studies are needed to determine whether K2-18b, which orbits a star 120 light-years away, is inhabited, or even habitable.

abstract: It will take a concerted effort by every sector of our society to respond to Trumpism’s threat.

abstract: After decades of conservative leadership, Francis tried to reset the course of the Roman Catholic Church, emphasizing inclusion and care for the marginalized over doctrinal purity.

title: The Trump Billionaires Who Run the Economy and the Things They Say
abstract: “You have to laugh to keep from crying,” one Republican pollster said about recent comments by the billionaires on the stock market, retirement funds and Social Security.

abstract: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent complained to President Trump that the acting commissioner had been installed without his knowledge.

title: Why Harvard Decided to Fight Trump
abstract: The Trump administration will freeze over $2 billion in federal funds because Harvard refused to comply with a list of demands. Harvard leaders believed saying no was worth the risk.

abstract: Baby bonuses and menstrual cycle classes are among the ideas pitched to Trump aides as they consider plans to try boosting the birthrate.

abstract: The participants discuss how they think Trump’s second term is going.

abstract: A group of transgender plaintiffs sued President Trump and the State Department over a new rule prohibiting passports from including a gender different from the sex listed on an original birth certificate.

abstract: Harvard’s lawsuit comes after the administration sought to force the university to comply with a list of demands by cutting billions in federal funding the school receives.

abstract: The draft executive order would eliminate Africa operations and shut down bureaus working on democracy, human rights and refugee issues.

abstract: The head of the federal Department of Transportation promised on Thursday to take away control of the project from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: An Age of Extinction Is Coming. Here’s How to Survive.
abstract: Everything is under threat. What you care about can make it to the other side.

abstract: A wide-ranging leading man who earned critical praise, he was known to be charismatic but unpredictable. At one point he dropped out of Hollywood for a decade.

abstract: Federal officials said they would freeze the money after Harvard said it would not submit to requests to overhaul hiring and report international students who break rules.

abstract: The Signal group chat is only the latest in a string of self-inflicted wounds by the new administration.

abstract: The New Jersey senator spent much of his speech, which ended after more than 25 hours, assailing the Trump administration. He eclipsed Strom Thurmond’s filibuster of a civil rights bill in 1957.

title: Wisconsin Supreme Court Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2025 Wisconsin spring elections.

abstract: A man was charged with setting fire to the residence, forcing Gov. Josh Shapiro and his family to flee. Investigators said they found beer bottles with gasoline inside the house.

abstract: The chat’s contents, which were obtained by The Atlantic after its editor in chief was added to the Signal group, provide a revealing look at private conversations between top Trump administration officials.

abstract: A trial judge had ordered the Trump administration to take steps to return the migrant, Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia, from a notorious prison in El Salvador.

abstract: If you’re within five years of retiring, either before or after, you’re at your most vulnerable financially. Here are steps to weather the volatility.

abstract: With diagnoses at a record high, some experts have begun to question our assumptions about the condition — and how to treat it.

abstract: Information about U.S. strikes in Yemen that the defense secretary put in two group chats came from Central Command, according to two people familiar with the chats.

abstract: Remarks by President Trump and his Treasury secretary fueled a rebound in global stocks, extending a surge that started on Wall Street.

abstract: The sharp rebuke by a federal judge in Maryland suggested that she had lost her patience with the Trump administration’s recalcitrance in the case.

abstract: Harvard’s lawyers suggest the administration was sloppy when it froze billions in federal funding. A mundane but crucial law is essential to the university’s case against the government.

abstract: Pope Francis’ funeral on Saturday will bring together leaders who sometimes clashed with the pope on issues such as global migration.

abstract: In a small ceremony, Vatican officials followed the path long taken when a pope dies.

abstract: Growing case numbers suggest that the national total will surpass that seen during the last large outbreak in 2019.

abstract: India had claimed in recent years that its heavy-handed approach had brought peace to the long restive region. The attack on Tuesday showed that wasn’t true.

abstract: Palisades Charter High School in California has held classes online since the fire in January. On Tuesday, students gathered at a new, temporary home, a retrofitted Sears.

abstract: Simple, affordable initiatives like rain gardens are helping to soak up water in New Orleans.

abstract: Pope Francis proved to be far more cautious and conservative than many progressive Catholics had hoped for.

abstract: Protesters interrupted an all-Balanchine program on the company’s spring season opening night, which coincided this year with Earth Day.

abstract: The singer summoned fans to an impromptu performance in Washington Square Park Tuesday night. She neglected to get a permit. But there was one more surprise to come.

abstract: Readers offer reflections after the death of Pope Francis. Also: The mistakes of Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth.

abstract: Writers, parents, doctors and legal experts have been arguing that social media is bad for teens. Turns out that worked.

abstract: Picking trade fights with countries across the Asia-Pacific plays right into Beijing’s plans to increase its sway over the region.

abstract: He helped L.G.B.T.Q. Catholics feel more at home in their church. And that meant their families and friends also felt more at home.

abstract: Papal weakness has also opened up other possibilities for Christian and Catholic witness.

abstract: In life and death, Francis wanted the symbols of his papacy to be humbler.

abstract: In a guest essay, the comedian warns that we should see people for who they really are.

abstract: For over half a century, the island’s commonwealth status was justified by promises of security, stability and the material comforts of modern life.

abstract: Every week, we’ll bring you stories that capture the wonders of the human body, nature and the cosmos.

abstract: A growing understanding of how “reproductive” hormones sculpt the brain could transform the management of neurological conditions.

abstract: Timberline Knolls, a mental health center owned by Acadia Healthcare, skimped on staff. Then came a series of tragedies.

abstract: Nine states have set goals to conserve 30 percent of their land by 2030. Maryland got there first.

abstract: A cluster of evangelical groups in the state is pushing for environmental action. Leaders say they’re following the biblical mandate to care for creation.

abstract: Every year for nearly two decades, the small city of Rock Port has been producing more electricity from wind energy than it needs.

abstract: A leading sociologist, he explored American society up close — living in a Levittown at one point — to gain insight into issues of race, class, the media and even the Yankees.

abstract: The cancellations, set to apply to pending and active grants, also affect research into “forever chemicals” contaminating the food supply.

abstract: For years a textile mill gave farmers its sewage sludge as free fertilizer. Today the land is full of “forever chemicals.”

abstract: An interim U.S. attorney is demanding information about the selection of research articles and the role of N.I.H. Experts worry this will have a chilling effect on publications.

abstract: A professional skeptic, he took on hundreds of mysteries, offering rational explanations for the Loch Ness monster, the Shroud of Turin and countless hauntings.

abstract: The president said the move was aimed at making the United States the world’s “dominant seafood leader.”

abstract: Eli Lilly said clinical results of its GLP-1 in pill form showed safety and efficacy data similar to blockbuster injectable drugs.

abstract: Extreme weather disasters, increasing as the planet warms, can curb blood donations while increasing demand, a new analysis found.

title: Countries Agree on Treaty Aimed at Preventing Global Health Crises
abstract: The World Health Organization finally reached a compromise on a pandemic treaty after three years of talks. The United States withdrew from negotiations after President Trump took office.
